b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:17): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: So I still don't understand how one is supposed to algorithmically determine what is a platform object and what is not, since the definition seems to be based on intent.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:18): Is it intended that platform objects have some hidden state that enables one to determine that they are platform objects?

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:19): If so is it intended that e.g. a third party javascript library can never implement an IDL interface (since the browser wouldn't know how to check for the hidden flag)
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (10:20): "An ECMAScript library that adds support for some Web API that is not natively supported by a browser would also be considered to expose platform objects."

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:20): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, there's a restriction now that platform objects (ones that aren't for exceptions, or platform array objects) can only implement "normal" interfaces and user objects can only implement callback interfaces
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:20): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, but yes because we aren't doing an explicit check on [[Class]] or whatever, there is some hidden state in there
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:21): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, how to determine whether a given object is considered to implement a given interface isn't defined exactly

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:21): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: Right I think that is my point. If a platform object is one that implements an interface and you can't tell what implements an interface you can't make platform objects

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:21): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, but there is a requirement that say an object returned from `readonly attribute Node? parentNode;` is a platform object that implements Node
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:22): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, just because platform objects are the only things that can implement (non-callback) interfaces

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:23): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, tbh I was a bit lazy, and I think the concept of platform vs user objects could probably be eliminated, since they are always distinct anyway (user objects can't implement Node, platform objects can't implement EventListener)

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:23): I am at least pretty sure than in the current state of the spec, the browser isPlatformObject check will basically amount to "is this implemented natively in the browser"
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (10:24): Sounds like the right thing to do

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:25): IIRC there is at least one situation where you need to take an arbitary object and determine if it is a platform object or not (overloading resolution with arrays, perhaps?)
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:25): "natively in the browser" is not exactly right; it's more like "has some hidden state variable set that only the given implementation would know"

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:25): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, there you need to know whether it is a native Array object (easy to check), a platform array object, or a platform object that also supports indexed properties
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:26): Either that is an equivalent statement or we will be in a bad state where some magic flags will have an effect on some browsers but not others
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:26): there's probably a problem
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:26): let's say you have the native browser C++ implementation of some APIs
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:26): as well as a JS library that implements some other APIs
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:26): the C++ implementation has an operation that takes a sequence
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:27): the JS library vends an object that supports indexed properties
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:27): how is the C++ implementation to know that the JS library objects "implements" the IDL interface with indexed properties
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:27): or even what that other IDL interface is
8b7a8196348038c107614af0b08f2d21 (10:28): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i haven't seen any -ibook stuff in WebKit, but I don't venture into CSS land much
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:28): I don't think it's possible then for a native C++ implementation and a JS library implementation of APIs to coexist
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:28): at least if they don't share knowledge about these internal state bits

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:30): I should probably remove mention of JS libraries implementing APIs, and talk more generally about it not mattering what languages (JS or C++) implements given interfaces, just that they need to share this internal state information
8b7a8196348038c107614af0b08f2d21 (10:30): i don't see anything about ibooks on http://opensource.apple.com/

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:32): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: I am a bit skeptical about something that would allow random on-the-web javascript libraries to set some flags that have magic behaviour in some implementations. Of course if some browser wants to implement their DOM APIs in javascript or a javascript/C++ mix, that should be possible

a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:33): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, so I should forget about random JS libraries
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (10:33): will have a go at writing that tomorrow
